El (Hebrew אֵל); the word is also used for god, god-like one, mighty one. - e.g. {Gen.16:13}
Eloah (Hebrew אֱלָהּ) / Elah (Aramaic אֱלֹהַּ); the words are also used for “god" or idol. - e.g. {Deut.32:15; Ezra.4:24}
Elohim (Hebrew אֱלֹהִים), the plural of Eloah; the word is also used for “gods" or idols. - e.g. {Gen.1:1}
Elyon / El Elyon (Hebrew אֵל עֶלְיוֹן) - e.g. {Gen.14:18; Num.24:16}
Adonai (Hebrew אֲדֹנָי); spoken in place of YHWH in Jewish display of reverence. - e.g. {Gen.15:2}
YHWH / Yahweh / Jehovah (Hebrew יְהוָה), the proper name of God. When translated, it is shown in capitals (“Lord") to distinguish from Adonai. - e.g. {Gen.2:4}
Yahweh Elohim (Hebrew יְהוָה אֱלֹהִים); a combination of the two names together. - e.g. {Gen.2:4; Ps.59:5}
Yahweh Jireh (Hebrew יְהוָה יִרְאֶה); the name, given to the place, where the Lord provided Abraham a sacrifice in place of Isaac. - e.g. {Gen.22:14}
Yahweh Nissi (Hebrew יְהוָה׀ נִסִּֽי); the name, given to an altar, where Abraham called on God by this name. - e.g. {Exod.17:15}
Yahweh Ro'i / Rohi (Hebrew יְהוָה רֹעִי); the Lord who shepherds or tends the flock. - e.g. {Ps.23:1}
Yahweh Sabaoth (Hebrew יְהוָה צְבָאוֹת); the Lord of the hosts (armies) of heaven. - e.g. {Isa.1:24}
Yahweh Shalom (Hebrew יְהוָה שָׁלוֹם); the name, given to an altar, built by Gideon to the Lord. - e.g. {Judg.6:24}
Yahweh Shammah (Hebrew יְהוָה׀ שָׁמָּה); the name given to a city, in Ezekiel’s prophecy, where the Lord would be forever. {Ezek.48:35}
The word Hashem (Hebrew הָשֵׁם) is used to avoid saying Yahweh. The word is not found explicitly in the Hebrew Scriptures referring to God.
El Ro'i (Hebrew אֵל רֳאִי); the name called by Hagar, for God had seen her. - e.g. {Gen.16:13}
God is also called the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, etc. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Gen.26:24}
Names, in addition to “Mighty God", given to the Son (Jesus) in Isaiah’s prophecy. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Isa.9:6}
The Name God told Moses to give to the Israelites in bondage in Egypt. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Exod.3:14}

Father - e.g. {Isa.63:16}
Our Redeemer from of old - e.g. {Isa.63:16}
Son of Man - e.g. {Dan.7:13}
The Ancient of Days - e.g. {Dan.7:9; Dan.7:13; Dan.7:22}
The Branch - e.g. {Zech.6:12; Jer.33:15; Isa.11:1}
Consuming Fire - e.g. {Deut.4:24; Heb.12:29}
Eternal One - e.g. {Isa.41:4}
The Holy One - e.g. {Isa.43:15}
Creator - e.g. {Isa.43:15}
God of the heavens - e.g. {Gen.24:3; Ezra.5:11}
Rock - e.g. {Deut.32:4}
God’s Spirit, the third person of the Trinity. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Matt.1:18}
Jesus (Greek Ἰησοῦς), or Joshua, means ‘Yahweh saves’
The Christ (Greek Χριστός) means the Chosen or Anointed One.
The Jewish leader from the line of David, for whom the Jews awaited
A title Jesus used to refer to Himself in the Gospels. The title was used in {Dan.7:13}. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Matt.8:20}
The title ‘Last Adam’ refers to Jesus as the new man, like Adam of Genesis, and yet without sin. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Rom.5:12-21; 1Cor.15:45}
The first and last Greek letters, indicating Jesus’ eternal being. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Rev.1:8}
Jesus is the Light of the World, the Bright Morning Star -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Rev.22:16}
Jesus is the cornerstone, the most important stone in a building’s foundation, of the Christian faith; a reference to {Ps.118:22-23}. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{Matt.21:42}
Jesus is the sacrificial Lamb, referring to the Passover lamb and {Isa.53:7}, who takes away the sins of the world. -&nbspe.g.&nbsp{John.1:29}

Jesus said, ‘I am’, a reference to {Exod.3:14}, stating He was God. - e.g. {John.8:58}
At His arrest, Jesus said, ‘I am [he]’, at which the soldiers stumbled backwards. - e.g. {John.18:5-8}

Bread of Life / Living Bread - e.g. {John.6:35}
Light of the World - e.g. {John.8:12}
Door - e.g. {John.10:7}
Good Shepherd - e.g. {John.10:11}
Resurrection and the Life - e.g. {John.11:25}
Way, Truth, and Life - e.g. {John.14:6}
Vine / True Vine - e.g. {John.15:1}
